Imagine 100 memories, 90 of which are far-removed in memory-space from the current context and favor action A, whilst 10 memories are closer to the current context and favor action B. By selectively sampling memories from the second group, the cascading process has a high probability of favoring action Beven though the vast majority of prior experiences favor action A. Additionally, when observing a context containing both features c and d, the cascading process is more likely to recall memories containing both of these features than any memories containing either c or d. As a result, the cascading process samples memories as if the conjoint probability c and d is larger than both the occurrence of either c or da clear example of the conjunction fallacy. The ability of the CASES framework to account for these behavioral regularities suggests that these distortions in our judgments are a logical consequence from our need to preferentially selected a limited number of relevant prior experiences from a large collection of irrelevant memories.

div.head: Sampling-to-threshold induces an availability heuristic
div.p: A related literature has developed around the availability heuristic (Tversky & Kahneman, 1974). That is, the meta-cognitive information provided by "the ease by with instances or occurrences can be brought to mind". Such availability follows from the CASES framework. As evidence is accumulated until a decision threshold has been reached, the ease through which memories are recalled provide a potential cognitive mechanism underpinning this heuristic. Depending on the level of this threshold, possibly only a small fraction of all memories will be sampled during the decision process, lending an exaggerated importance to memories which are activated early in the cascading chain. That is, to memories which are relatively similar to the decision context and thus come to mind more readily. For sufficiently low levels of the decision threshold τ, the recall of these early memories may saturate the threshold, resulting in the decision-maker behaving in accordance with the availability heuristic. Consequentially, the random walk of the CASES framework suggests a putative computational underpinning for the availability heuristic, re-conceptualizing this heuristic as a consequence of a bottom-up memory search process.

div.head: Cascading sampling can capture both fast and slow decisions
div.p: Previous research in decision science has proposed dual-system approaches in which decisionmakers can utilize either a fast and automatic, or slow and deliberative, decision system (Kahneman, 2011). The CASES framework suggests a putative mechanism whereby both systems can be captured though a different parameterization of the same underlying cognitive process, that is, both 'systems' may result from different levels of the decision threshold τ. Decisions (or individual actions within a decision) with a low threshold require a limited number of memories to be sampled before an action is selectedresulting in a fast reaction time and an action being selected on the basis of the availability heuristic. In contrast, decisions (or individual actions) with higher thresholds levels require a larger number of sampled experiences to reach this thresholdresulting in slower decision times, a mitigation of the availability heuristic and a wider 'exploration' of episodic memory-space. Different thresholds can thus result in the selection of different actions at different decision speeds. Consequentially, CASES re-conceptualized both fast and automatic, as well as slow and deliberative decisions as different outcomes of a single underlying memory-sampling system.

div.head: Concluding Remarks
div.p: In this work we outlined a framework to capture our ability to sample episodic memories to inform everyday decisions. Starting from five key principles regarding the storage and retrieval of memories, we proposed a framework of Cascading Episodic Sampling. The random walk through memory-space that results from this framework allows for the selective sampling of relevant experiences in everyday life. Moreover, the framework offers a parsimonious umbrella to bridge between previous models of memory-based decisionsas well as offering a series of novel perspectives on previously observed behavioural regularities.

By supporting the bottom-up sampling of relevant episodic memories, CASES fills a limited yet important niche within our complex decision-making machinery. This is not to imply that there are no other sources of information that range beyond the retrieval of episodic memories. Abstract associations and statistical regularities can be extracted across multiple memories, which has previously been explored in a range of theoretical works describing the learning of abstract categories of features, either through the formation of abstract prototypes (Homa & et al, 1973;Posner & Keele, 1968;Reed, 1972) or exemplars (Kruschke, 1992;Medin & Schaffer, 1978;Nosofsky, 1986Nosofsky, , 1988. Of particular note is previous research suggesting that such abstracted information may be retrieved through a random walk in semantic memory-space (Hills et al., 2012;Howard & Kahana, 2002;Lohnas et al., 2015;Polyn et al., 2009), as well as evidence suggesting that these abstract representations of communalities can be used to limit which memories may be evaluated during the decision process (Humphreys et al., 1989;Osth & Dennis, 2015;Polyn et al., 2009;Zhang et al., 2021).

The combination of CASES with such abstract representations suggests a rich and dynamic system of interactions between the recollection of episodic memories and abstract knowledge; the episodic random walk reinstates memories and their constituent features, whilst the abstract representations bias the activation of features along abstract communalities learned across multiple memories. Future explorations of the interplay between the random walks in episodic memory-space, semantic memory and learned categories therefore offers a fertile ground for new insights into the complex interactions between these systems during decisions made in everyday life.

The mechanisms outlined in this work are certainly simplifications and omit many of the nuances inherent to the subfields covered in this article. Following George Box ("all models are wrong, but some are useful"), our goal in the current work was not to provide a detailed blueprint of all memory-based decisions. Instead, our aim was to illustrate the core idea that cascading recall is a compelling candidate to underpin our ability retrieve relevant prior experiences to guide decisions in novel situations, as well as allowing for the integration of previously disparate views, findings, and theories of the processes that allow for decisionmaking in daily life. By doing so, CASES offers a novel perspective on the cognitive processes that support our ability to navigate the rich reality of everyday day life. It is our hope that the CASES framework will spark a cascade of research of its own, leading to new ideas and models to explore the varied role of episodic memories in everyday life.

figure.head: Figure 2 :
figure.figDesc: Experiment Design for the Fennimals Task Note. Each Fennimal consisted of two variable features (A), with each Fennimal consisting of one of eight different types and one of six different color/background combinations. (B) schematic overview of the experiment procedure.

figure.head: Figure 4 :
figure.figDesc: Setup and results for the second experiment Note. During the training phase participants encountered four Fennimals, each associated with a unique toy. Fennimals shared overlapping features, with two Fennimals (a and b) sharing a color/background and two Fennimals (c and d) sharing a type. During the test phase participants encountered a novel Fennimal which shared either a type or color with one previously encountered Fennimal. Participants could not select the toy associated with this directly overlapping Fennimal, but could select the toy associated with the indirectly associated (paired) Fennimal. In line with the hypothesized cascading recall process (the recall of the directly related Fennimal triggers the recall of the indirectly related Fennimal, predictions indicated by the highlighted option), participants selecting the indirectly associated item in 49% of trials, significantly more than would be expected by chance alone (33%). This effect is consistent over all four test trial types. Pictured Fennimals are an example only; all Fennimals and item-associations were randomized on a between-subject basis. Highlighted options for illustration only, none of the options were highlighted on the participant's screen.

figure.head: Figure 5 :
figure.figDesc: Setup and results for the third experiment Note. During the training phase participants encountered four Fennimals, each associated with a unique item. Two Fennimals (c & d) shared a color and background. The test phase consisted of two types of trials.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: We thank all the comments, feedback and support that have contributed to various iterations of this work over the years. In particular, we thank the institutions which supported a large fraction of this work: the Nijmegen School of Management and the Donders Institute at Radboud University Nijmegen, as well as the Faculty of Society and Economics at the Rhein-Waal University of Applied Sciences.
